**Ottawa** ([/ˈɒtəwə/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English") ([![About
this
sound](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-
Loudspeaker.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Ottawa.ogg "About this sound")
[listen](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/60/Ottawa.ogg
"Ottawa.ogg")), [/-wɑː/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English"); French
pronunciation: ​[[ɔtawa]](/wiki/Help:IPA/French "Help:IPA/French")) is the
[capital city](/wiki/Capital_city "Capital city") of [Canada](/wiki/Canada
"Canada"). It stands on the south bank of the [Ottawa
River](/wiki/Ottawa_River "Ottawa River") in the [eastern
portion](/wiki/Eastern_Ontario "Eastern Ontario") of [southern
Ontario](/wiki/Southern_Ontario "Southern Ontario"). Ottawa borders
[Gatineau](/wiki/Gatineau "Gatineau"), [Quebec](/wiki/Quebec "Quebec"); the
two form the core of the Ottawa–Gatineau [census metropolitan
area](/wiki/Census_metropolitan_area "Census metropolitan area") (CMA) and the
[National Capital Region](/wiki/National_Capital_Region_\(Canada\) "National
Capital Region \(Canada\)") (NCR).[12] As of 2016, Ottawa had a city
population of 964,743 and a metropolitan population of 1,323,783 making it the
[fourth-largest
city](/wiki/List_of_the_100_largest_municipalities_in_Canada_by_population
"List of the 100 largest municipalities in Canada by population") and the
[fifth-largest
CMA](/wiki/List_of_census_metropolitan_areas_and_agglomerations_in_Canada
"List of census metropolitan areas and agglomerations in Canada") in Canada.

Founded in 1826 as [Bytown](/wiki/Bytown "Bytown"), and
[incorporated](/wiki/Municipal_corporation "Municipal corporation") as Ottawa
in 1855, the city has evolved into the political centre of Canada. Its
original boundaries were expanded through numerous annexations and were
ultimately replaced by a new city incorporation and amalgamation in 2001 which
significantly increased its land area. The city name "Ottawa" was chosen in
reference to the Ottawa River, the name of which is derived from the
[Algonquin](/wiki/Algonquin_language "Algonquin language") _Odawa_ , meaning
"to trade".[13]

Ottawa has the most educated population among Canadian cities[14] and is home
to a number of post-secondary, research, and cultural institutions, including
the [National Arts Centre](/wiki/National_Arts_Centre_\(Canada\) "National
Arts Centre \(Canada\)"), the [National
Gallery](/wiki/National_Gallery_\(Canada\) "National Gallery \(Canada\)"), and
numerous national museums. Ottawa has the highest standard of living in the
nation and low unemployment.

## History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ottawa&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: History")]

Main article: [History of Ottawa](/wiki/History_of_Ottawa "History of Ottawa")

See also: [Timeline of Ottawa history](/wiki/Timeline_of_Ottawa_history
"Timeline of Ottawa history")

With the draining of the [Champlain Sea](/wiki/Champlain_Sea "Champlain Sea")
around ten thousand years ago, the [Ottawa Valley](/wiki/Ottawa_Valley "Ottawa
Valley") became habitable.[15] Local populations used the area for wild edible
harvesting, hunting, fishing, trade, travel, and camps for over 6500 years.
The Ottawa river valley has archaeological sites with arrow heads, pottery,
and stone tools. Three major rivers meet within Ottawa, making it an important
trade and travel area for thousands of years.[16] The
[Algonquins](/wiki/Algonquin_people "Algonquin people") called the [Ottawa
River](/wiki/Ottawa_River "Ottawa River") _Kichi Sibi_ or _Kichissippi_
meaning "Great River" or "Grand River".[17][18][19][20]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/First_camp_by_By.jpg/220px-
First_camp_by_By.jpg)](/wiki/File:First_camp_by_By.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:First_camp_by_By.jpg "Enlarge")

Camp used by soldiers and labourers of the [Rideau Canal](/wiki/Rideau_Canal
"Rideau Canal"), on the south side of the [Ottawa River](/wiki/Ottawa_River
"Ottawa River") in 1826. The building of the canal attracted many land
speculators to the area.

[Étienne Brûlé](/wiki/%C3%89tienne_Br%C3%BBl%C3%A9 "Étienne Brûlé"), widely
regarded as the first European to travel up the Ottawa River, passed by Ottawa
in 1610 on his way to the [Great Lakes](/wiki/Great_Lakes "Great Lakes").[18]
Three years later, [Samuel de Champlain](/wiki/Samuel_de_Champlain "Samuel de
Champlain") wrote about the waterfalls in the area and about his encounters
with the Algonquins, who had been using the Ottawa River for centuries.[21]
Many missionaries would follow the early explorers and traders. The first maps
of the area used the word Ottawa, derived from the Algonquin word _adawe_ ("to
trade", used in reference to the area's importance to First Nations traders),
to name the river. [Philemon Wright](/wiki/Philemon_Wright "Philemon Wright"),
a [New Englander](/wiki/New_England "New England"), created the first
settlement in the area on 7 March 1800 on the north side of the river, across
from the present day city of Ottawa in [Hull](/wiki/Hull,_Quebec "Hull,
Quebec").[22][23] He, with five other families and twenty-five labourers,[17]
set about to create an agricultural community[24] called Wrightsville. Wright
pioneered the [Ottawa Valley timber trade](/wiki/Ottawa_River_timber_trade
"Ottawa River timber trade") (soon to be the area's most significant economic
activity) by transporting timber by river from the Ottawa Valley to Quebec
City.[25] [Bytown](/wiki/Bytown "Bytown"), Ottawa's original name, was founded
as a community in 1826 when hundreds of land speculators were attracted to the
south side of the river when news spread that British authorities were
immediately constructing the northerly end of the [Rideau
Canal](/wiki/Rideau_Canal "Rideau Canal") military project at that
location.[26][27] The following year, the town was named after British
military engineer Colonel [John By](/wiki/John_By "John By") who was
responsible for the entire Rideau Waterway construction project.

The canal's military purpose was to provide a secure route between Montreal
and [Kingston](/wiki/Kingston,_Ontario "Kingston, Ontario") on [Lake
Ontario](/wiki/Lake_Ontario "Lake Ontario"), bypassing a particularly
vulnerable stretch of the [St. Lawrence River](/wiki/St._Lawrence_River "St.
Lawrence River") bordering the state of [New York](/wiki/New_York_\(state\)
"New York \(state\)") that had left re-supply ships bound for southwestern
Ontario easily exposed to enemy fire during the [War of
1812](/wiki/War_of_1812 "War of 1812").[28] Colonel By set up military
barracks on the site of today's [Parliament Hill](/wiki/Parliament_Hill
"Parliament Hill"). He also laid out the streets of the town and created two
distinct neighbourhoods named "Upper Town" west of the canal and "[Lower
Town](/wiki/Lower_Town "Lower Town")" east of the canal. Similar to its [Upper
Canada](/wiki/Upper_Canada "Upper Canada") and [Lower
Canada](/wiki/Lower_Canada "Lower Canada") namesakes, historically 'Upper
Town' was predominantly English speaking and Protestant whereas 'Lower Town'
was predominantly French, Irish and Catholic.[29] Bytown's population grew to
1,000 as the Rideau Canal was being completed in 1832.[30][31] Bytown
encountered some impassioned and violent times in her early pioneer period
that included Irish labour unrest that attributed to the [Shiners'
War](/wiki/Shiners%27_War "Shiners' War") from 1835 to 1845[32] and political
dissension that was evident from the 1849 [Stony Monday
Riot](/wiki/Stony_Monday_Riot "Stony Monday Riot").[33] In 1855 Bytown was
renamed _Ottawa_ and incorporated as a city.[34] [William Pittman
Lett](/wiki/William_Pittman_Lett "William Pittman Lett") was installed as the
first city clerk guiding it through 36 years of development. [35]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/View_of_Parliament_Hill_and_Chaudi%C3%A8re_Falls._%22City_of_Ottawa%2C_Canada_West%22%2C_ca._1859%2C_by_Stent_and_Laver..jpg/220px-
View_of_Parliament_Hill_and_Chaudi%C3%A8re_Falls._%22City_of_Ottawa%2C_Canada_West%22%2C_ca._1859%2C_by_Stent_and_Laver..jpg)](/wiki/File:View_of_Parliament_Hill_and_Chaudi%C3%A8re_Falls._%22City_of_Ottawa,_Canada_West%22,_ca._1859,_by_Stent_and_Laver..jpg)

[](/wiki/File:View_of_Parliament_Hill_and_Chaudi%C3%A8re_Falls._%22City_of_Ottawa,_Canada_West%22,_ca._1859,_by_Stent_and_Laver..jpg
"Enlarge")

View of Ottawa in 1859, prior to the start of construction on [Parliament
Hill](/wiki/Parliament_Hill "Parliament Hill"). Two years prior, [Queen
Victoria](/wiki/Queen_Victoria "Queen Victoria") selected the city as the
permanent capital of the [Province of Canada](/wiki/Province_of_Canada
"Province of Canada").

On New Year's Eve 1857, [Queen Victoria](/wiki/Queen_Victoria "Queen
Victoria"), as a symbolic and political gesture, was presented with the
responsibility of selecting a location for the permanent capital of the
[Province of Canada](/wiki/Province_of_Canada "Province of Canada").[36] In
reality, Prime Minister [John A. Macdonald](/wiki/John_A._Macdonald "John A.
Macdonald") had assigned this selection process to the [Executive
Branch](/wiki/Executive_\(government\) "Executive \(government\)") of the
Government, as previous attempts to arrive at a consensus had ended in
deadlock.[37] The 'Queen's choice' turned out to be the small frontier town of
Ottawa for two main reasons:[38] Firstly, Ottawa's isolated location in a back
country surrounded by dense forest far from the Canada–US border and situated
on a cliff face would make it more defensible from attack.[39][40] Secondly,
Ottawa was approximately midway between [Toronto](/wiki/Toronto "Toronto") and
[Kingston](/wiki/Kingston,_Ontario "Kingston, Ontario") (in [Canada
West](/wiki/Canada_West "Canada West")) and [Montreal](/wiki/Montreal
"Montreal") and [Quebec City](/wiki/Quebec_City "Quebec City") (in [Canada
East](/wiki/Canada_East "Canada East")). Additionally, despite Ottawa's
regional isolation it had seasonal water transportation access to Montreal
over the Ottawa River and to Kingston via the [Rideau
Waterway](/wiki/Rideau_Waterway "Rideau Waterway"). By 1854 it also had a
modern all season [Bytown and Prescott
Railway](/wiki/Bytown_and_Prescott_Railway "Bytown and Prescott Railway") that
carried passengers, lumber and supplies the 82-kilometres to
[Prescott](/wiki/Prescott,_Ontario "Prescott, Ontario") on the [Saint Lawrence
River](/wiki/Saint_Lawrence_River "Saint Lawrence River") and beyond.[17][39]
Ottawa's small size, it was thought, would make it less prone to rampaging
politically motivated mobs, as had happened in the [previous Canadian
capitals](/wiki/Burning_of_the_Parliament_Buildings_in_Montreal "Burning of
the Parliament Buildings in Montreal").[41] The government already owned the
land that would eventually become Parliament Hill which they thought would be
an ideal location for building the Parliament Buildings. Ottawa was the only
settlement of any substantial size that was already directly on the border of
French populated former Lower Canada and English populated former Upper Canada
thus additionally making the selection an important political compromise.[42]
Queen Victoria made her "Queen's choice" very quickly just before welcoming in
the New Year.

Starting in the 1850s, entrepreneurs known as lumber barons began to build
large sawmills, which became some of the largest mills in the world.[43] Rail
lines built in 1854 connected Ottawa to areas south and to the
transcontinental rail network via Hull and [Lachute](/wiki/Lachute "Lachute"),
Quebec in 1886.[44] The original Parliament buildings which included the
Centre, East and West Blocks were constructed between 1859 and 1866 in the
[Gothic Revival style](/wiki/Gothic_Revival_architecture "Gothic Revival
architecture").[45] At the time, this was the largest North American
construction project ever attempted and [Public Works
Canada](/wiki/Public_Works_Canada "Public Works Canada") and its architects
were not initially well prepared. The [Library of
Parliament](/wiki/Library_of_Parliament "Library of Parliament") and
Parliament Hill landscaping would not be completed until 1876.[46] By 1885
Ottawa was the only city in Canada whose downtown street lights were powered
entirely by electricity.[47] In 1889 the Government developed and distributed
60 'water leases' (still currently in use) to mainly local industrialists
which gave them permission to generate electricity and operate hydroelectric
generators at [Chaudière Falls](/wiki/Chaudi%C3%A8re_Falls "Chaudière
Falls").[48] Public transportation began in 1870 with a
[horsecar](/wiki/Horsecar "Horsecar") system,[49] overtaken in the 1890s by a
vast [electric streetcar system](/wiki/Ottawa_Electric_Railway "Ottawa
Electric Railway") that lasted until 1959.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Lebreton_Flats_after_1900_fire.jpg/220px-
Lebreton_Flats_after_1900_fire.jpg)](/wiki/File:Lebreton_Flats_after_1900_fire.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Lebreton_Flats_after_1900_fire.jpg "Enlarge")

[Lebreton Flats](/wiki/Lebreton_Flats "Lebreton Flats") after the [1900
Hull–Ottawa fire](/wiki/1900_Hull%E2%80%93Ottawa_fire "1900 Hull–Ottawa
fire"). The fire destroyed one-fifth of Ottawa, and two-thirds of neighbouring
[Hull](/wiki/Hull,_Quebec "Hull, Quebec"), [Quebec](/wiki/Quebec "Quebec").

The [Hull–Ottawa fire of 1900](/wiki/1900_Hull%E2%80%93Ottawa_fire "1900
Hull–Ottawa fire") destroyed two-thirds of Hull, including 40 per cent of its
residential buildings and most of its largest employers along the
waterfront.[50] It also spread across the Ottawa River and destroyed about one
fifth of Ottawa from the [Lebreton Flats](/wiki/Lebreton_Flats "Lebreton
Flats") south to [Booth Street](/wiki/Booth_Street "Booth Street") and down to
[Dow's Lake](/wiki/Dow%27s_Lake "Dow's Lake").[51] On 1 June 1912 the [Grand
Trunk Railway](/wiki/Grand_Trunk_Railway "Grand Trunk Railway") opened both
the [Château Laurier](/wiki/Ch%C3%A2teau_Laurier "Château Laurier") hotel and
its neighbouring downtown [Union Station](/wiki/Union_Station_\(Ottawa\)
"Union Station \(Ottawa\)").[52][53] On 3 February 1916 the [Centre
Block](/wiki/Centre_Block "Centre Block") of the Parliament buildings was
[destroyed by a fire](/wiki/Parliament_Hill#Fire,_rebuilding,_and_beyond
"Parliament Hill").[54] The House of Commons and Senate was temporarily
relocated to the then recently constructed Victoria Memorial Museum, now the
[Canadian Museum of Nature](/wiki/Canadian_Museum_of_Nature "Canadian Museum
of Nature")[55] until the completion of the new Centre Block in 1922, the
centrepiece of which is a dominant [Gothic](/wiki/Gothic_architecture "Gothic
architecture") revival styled structure known as the [Peace
Tower](/wiki/Peace_Tower "Peace Tower").[56] The current location of what is
now [Confederation Square](/wiki/Confederation_Square "Confederation Square")
was a former commercial district centrally located in a triangular area
downtown surrounded by historically significant heritage buildings which
includes the Parliament buildings. It was redeveloped as a ceremonial centre
in 1938 as part of the [City Beautiful Movement](/wiki/City_Beautiful_Movement
"City Beautiful Movement") and became the site of the [National War
Memorial](/wiki/National_War_Memorial_\(Canada\) "National War Memorial
\(Canada\)") in 1939 and designated a [National Historic
Site](/wiki/National_Historic_Sites_of_Canada "National Historic Sites of
Canada") in 1984.[57] A new [Central Post
Office](/wiki/Central_Post_Office_\(Ottawa\) "Central Post Office \(Ottawa\)")
(now the [Privy Council of Canada](/wiki/Privy_Council_of_Canada "Privy
Council of Canada")) was constructed in 1939 beside the War Memorial because
the original post office building on the proposed Confederation Square grounds
had to be demolished.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/Ottawagreenbelt.PNG/220px-
Ottawagreenbelt.PNG)](/wiki/File:Ottawagreenbelt.PNG)

[](/wiki/File:Ottawagreenbelt.PNG "Enlarge")

Greber plan's [ National Capital Greenbelt](/wiki/Greenbelt_\(Ottawa\)
"Greenbelt \(Ottawa\)") surrounding the urban core.

Ottawa's former industrial appearance was vastly altered by the 1950 [Greber
Plan](/wiki/Greber_Plan "Greber Plan"). Prime Minister [Mackenzie
King](/wiki/Mackenzie_King "Mackenzie King") hired French architect-planner
[Jacques Greber](/wiki/Jacques_Greber "Jacques Greber") to design an urban
plan for managing development in the National Capital Region, to make it more
aesthetically pleasing and more befitting a location for Canada's political
centre.[58][59] Greber's plan included the creation of the [National Capital
Greenbelt](/wiki/Greenbelt_\(Ottawa\) "Greenbelt \(Ottawa\)"), the
[Parkway](/wiki/Sir_John_A._Macdonald_Parkway "Sir John A. Macdonald
Parkway"), the [Queensway](/wiki/Queensway_\(Ottawa\) "Queensway \(Ottawa\)")
highway system, the relocation of downtown Union Station (now the [Government
Conference Centre](/wiki/Government_Conference_Centre "Government Conference
Centre")) to the suburbs, the removal of the street car system, the
decentralization of selected government offices, the relocation of industries
and removal of substandard housing from the downtown and the creation of the
Rideau Canal and Ottawa River pathways to name just a few of its
recommendations.[58][60][61] In 1958 the [National Capital
Commission](/wiki/National_Capital_Commission "National Capital Commission")
was established as a [Crown Corporation](/wiki/Crown_Corporation "Crown
Corporation") from the passing of the National Capital Act to implement the
Greber Plan recommendations-which it accomplished during the 1960s and 1970s.

In the previous 50 years, other commissions, plans and projects had failed to
implement plans to improve the capital such as the 1899 Ottawa Improvement
Commission (OIC), The Todd Plan in 1903, The Holt Report in 1915 and The
Federal District Commission (FDC) established in 1927.[62] In 1958 a new [City
Hall](/wiki/Old_City_Hall_\(Ottawa\) "Old City Hall \(Ottawa\)") opened on
Green Island near Rideau falls where urban renewal had recently transformed
this former industrial location into green space.[63] Until then, City Hall
had temporarily been located for 27 years (1931–1958) at the [Transportation
Building](/wiki/Transportation_Building_\(Ottawa\) "Transportation Building
\(Ottawa\)") adjacent to Union Station and now part of the [Rideau
Centre](/wiki/CF_Rideau_Centre "CF Rideau Centre"). In 2001, [Ottawa City
Hall](/wiki/Ottawa_City_Hall "Ottawa City Hall") returned downtown to a
relatively new building (1990) on 110 Laurier Avenue West, the prior home of
the now defunct [Regional Municipality of Ottawa-
Carleton](/wiki/Regional_Municipality_of_Ottawa-Carleton "Regional
Municipality of Ottawa-Carleton"). This new location was close to Ottawa's
[first (1849–1877)](/wiki/First_City_Hall_\(Ottawa\) "First City Hall
\(Ottawa\)") and [second (1877–1931)](/wiki/Second_City_Hall_\(Ottawa\)
"Second City Hall \(Ottawa\)") City Halls. This new city hall complex also
contained an adjacent 19th century restored heritage building formerly known
as the [Ottawa Normal School](/wiki/Ottawa_Normal_School "Ottawa Normal
School").[63]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Ottawa%2C_Canada_%2819923366799%29.jpg/220px-
Ottawa%2C_Canada_%2819923366799%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ottawa,_Canada_\(19923366799\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Ottawa,_Canada_\(19923366799\).jpg "Enlarge")

The [John G. Diefenbaker Building](/wiki/John_G._Diefenbaker_Building "John G.
Diefenbaker Building") was Ottawa's fourth city hall. Opened in 1958, it was
the seat of local government until the City Council moved to its [present
location](/wiki/Ottawa_City_Hall "Ottawa City Hall") in 2001.

From the 1960s until the 1980s, the National Capital Region experienced a
building boom, [64] which was followed by large growth in the [high-
tech](/wiki/High-tech "High-tech") industry during the 1990s and 2000s.[65]
Ottawa became one of Canada's largest [high tech](/wiki/High_tech "High tech")
cities and was nicknamed Silicon Valley North. By the 1980s, Bell Northern
Research (later [Nortel](/wiki/Nortel "Nortel")) employed thousands, and large
federally assisted research facilities such as the [National Research
Council](/wiki/National_Research_Council_\(Canada\) "National Research Council
\(Canada\)") contributed to an eventual technology boom. The early adopters
led to offshoot companies such as [Newbridge
Networks](/wiki/Newbridge_Networks "Newbridge Networks"), [Mitel](/wiki/Mitel
"Mitel") and [Corel](/wiki/Corel "Corel").

Ottawa's city limits had been increasing over the years, but it acquired the
most territory on 1 January 2001, when it amalgamated all the municipalities
of the [Regional Municipality of
Ottawa–Carleton](/wiki/Regional_Municipality_of_Ottawa%E2%80%93Carleton
"Regional Municipality of Ottawa–Carleton") into one single city.[66] Regional
Chair [Bob Chiarelli](/wiki/Bob_Chiarelli "Bob Chiarelli") was elected as the
new city's first mayor in the [2000 municipal
election](/wiki/Ottawa_municipal_election,_2000 "Ottawa municipal election,
2000"), defeating [Gloucester](/wiki/Gloucester,_Ontario "Gloucester,
Ontario") mayor [Claudette Cain](/wiki/Claudette_Cain "Claudette Cain"). The
city's growth led to strains on the public transit system and on road bridges.
On 15 October 2001, a diesel-powered [light rail
transit](/wiki/Light_rail_transit "Light rail transit") (LRT) line was
introduced on an experimental basis. Known today as the [Trillium
Line](/wiki/Trillium_Line "Trillium Line"), it was dubbed the
[O-Train](/wiki/O-Train "O-Train") and connected [downtown
Ottawa](/wiki/Downtown_Ottawa "Downtown Ottawa") to the southern suburbs via
[Carleton University](/wiki/Carleton_University "Carleton University"). The
decision to extend the O-Train, and to replace it with an electric light rail
system was a major issue in the [2006 municipal
elections](/wiki/Ottawa_municipal_election,_2006 "Ottawa municipal election,
2006") where Chiarelli was defeated by businessman [Larry
O'Brien](/wiki/Larry_O%27Brien_\(Canadian_politician\) "Larry O'Brien
\(Canadian politician\)"). After O'Brien's election transit plans were changed
to establish a series of light rail stations from the east side of the city
into downtown, and for using a tunnel through the downtown core. [Jim
Watson](/wiki/Jim_Watson_\(Canadian_politician\) "Jim Watson \(Canadian
politician\)"), the last mayor of Ottawa prior to amalgamation, was re-elected
in the [2010 election](/wiki/Ottawa_municipal_election,_2010 "Ottawa municipal
election, 2010").[67]

In October 2012, City Council approved the final Lansdowne Park plan, an
agreement with the Ottawa Sports and Entertainment Group that saw a new
stadium, increased green space, and housing and retail added to the
site.[68][69] In December 2012, City Council voted unanimously to move forward
with the [Confederation Line](/wiki/Confederation_Line "Confederation Line"),
a 12.5 km light rail transit line, to be fully operational by 2018.[70]

## Geography[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ottawa&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Geography")]

Main article: [Geography of Ottawa](/wiki/Geography_of_Ottawa "Geography of
Ottawa")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Hot_Air_Balloon_ride_Ottawa_II.jpg/220px-
Hot_Air_Balloon_ride_Ottawa_II.jpg)](/wiki/File:Hot_Air_Balloon_ride_Ottawa_II.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Hot_Air_Balloon_ride_Ottawa_II.jpg "Enlarge")

[Downtown Ottawa](/wiki/Downtown_Ottawa "Downtown Ottawa") is situated on the
south bank of the [Ottawa River](/wiki/Ottawa_River "Ottawa River").
[Gatineau](/wiki/Gatineau "Gatineau") may be seen in the background, across
the river.

Ottawa is on the south bank of the Ottawa River and contains the mouths of the
[Rideau River](/wiki/Rideau_River "Rideau River") and Rideau Canal.[71] The
older part of the city (including what remains of Bytown) is known as _Lower
Town_ , and occupies an area between the canal and the rivers. Across the
canal to the west lies _[Centretown](/wiki/Centretown "Centretown")_ and
_Downtown Ottawa_ , which is the city's financial and commercial hub and home
to the [Parliament of Canada](/wiki/Parliament_of_Canada "Parliament of
Canada") and numerous federal government department headquarters, notably the
[Privy Council Office](/wiki/Privy_Council_Office_\(Canada\) "Privy Council
Office \(Canada\)"). On 29 June 2007, the Rideau Canal, which stretches 202 km
(126 mi) to Kingston, Fort Henry and four Martello towers in the Kingston
area, was recognized as a [UNESCO World Heritage
Site](/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Site "UNESCO World Heritage Site").[72]

Located within the major, yet mostly dormant [Western Quebec Seismic
Zone](/wiki/Western_Quebec_Seismic_Zone "Western Quebec Seismic Zone"),[73]
Ottawa is occasionally struck by earthquakes. Examples include the [2000
Kipawa earthquake](/wiki/2000_Kipawa_earthquake "2000 Kipawa earthquake"),[74]
a magnitude-4.5 earthquake on 24 February 2006,[75] the [2010 Central Canada
earthquake](/wiki/2010_Central_Canada_earthquake "2010 Central Canada
earthquake"),[76] and a magnitude-5.2 earthquake on 17 May 2013.[77]

Ottawa sits at the confluence of three major rivers: the Ottawa River, the
[Gatineau River](/wiki/Gatineau_River "Gatineau River") and the Rideau
River.[78] The Ottawa and Gatineau rivers were historically important in the
logging and lumber industries and the Rideau as part of the Rideau Canal
system for military, commercial and, subsequently, recreational purposes.[78]
The Rideau Canal (Rideau Waterway) first opened in 1832 and is 202 km long. It
connects the Saint Lawrence River on Lake Ontario at Kingston to the Ottawa
River near Parliament Hill. It was able to bypass the unnavigable sections of
the [Cataraqui](/wiki/Cataraqui_River "Cataraqui River") and Rideau rivers and
various small lakes along the waterway due to flooding techniques and the
construction of 47 water transport [locks.](/wiki/Lock_\(water_transport\)
"Lock \(water transport\)")The Rideau River got its name from early French
explorers who thought that the waterfalls located at the point where the
Rideau River empties into the Ottawa River resembled a 'curtain'. Hence they
began naming the falls and river 'rideau' which is the French equivalent of
the English word for curtain.[79][21] During part of the winter season the
Ottawa section of the canal forms the world's largest skating rink, thereby
providing both a recreational venue and a 7.8 kilometres (4.8 mi)
transportation path to downtown for ice skaters (from Carleton University and
Dow's Lake to the Rideau Centre and [National Arts
Centre](/wiki/National_Arts_Centre "National Arts Centre")).[80]

Across the Ottawa River, which forms the border between Ontario and
[Quebec](/wiki/Quebec "Quebec"), lies the city of [Gatineau](/wiki/Gatineau
"Gatineau"), itself the result of amalgamation of the former Quebec cities of
[Hull](/wiki/Hull_\(Quebec\) "Hull \(Quebec\)") and
[Aylmer](/wiki/Aylmer_\(Quebec\) "Aylmer \(Quebec\)") together with
Gatineau.[81] Although formally and administratively separate cities in two
separate provinces, Ottawa and Gatineau (along with a number of nearby
municipalities) collectively constitute the [National Capital
Region](/wiki/National_Capital_Region_\(Canada\) "National Capital Region
\(Canada\)"), which is considered a single metropolitan area. One federal
crown corporation, the National Capital Commission, or NCC, has significant
land holdings in both cities, including sites of historical and touristic
importance. The NCC, through its responsibility for planning and development
of these lands, is an important contributor to both cities. Around the main
urban area is an extensive [greenbelt](/wiki/Greenbelt "Greenbelt"),
administered by the NCC for conservation and leisure, and comprising mostly
forest, farmland and marshland.[82]

### Climate[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ottawa&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Climate")]

Ottawa has a [humid continental climate](/wiki/Humid_continental_climate
"Humid continental climate")
([Köppen](/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification "Köppen climate
classification") _Dfb_)[83] with four distinct seasons and is between Zones 5a
and 5b on the Canadian Plant Hardiness Scale.[84] The average July maximum
temperature is 26.6 °C (80 °F). The average January minimum temperature is
−14.4 °C (6.1 °F)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Ottawa_Rideau_Canal_Skating_Chateau_Laurier_Parliament.jpg/220px-
Ottawa_Rideau_Canal_Skating_Chateau_Laurier_Parliament.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ottawa_Rideau_Canal_Skating_Chateau_Laurier_Parliament.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Ottawa_Rideau_Canal_Skating_Chateau_Laurier_Parliament.jpg
"Enlarge")

Skating on the Rideau Canal. Snow and ice is common for the region during the
winter.

Summers are warm and humid in Ottawa. On average 11 days of the three summer
months have temperatures exceeding 30 °C (86 °F), or 37 days if the
[humidex](/wiki/Humidex "Humidex") is considered. Average relative humidity
averages 54% in the afternoon and 84% by morning.

Snow and ice are dominant during the winter season. On average Ottawa receives
224 centimetres (88 in) of snowfall annually but maintains an average 22
centimetres (9 in) of snowpack throughout the three winter months. An average
16 days of the three winter months experience temperatures below −20 °C (−4
°F), or 41 days if the [wind chill](/wiki/Wind_chill "Wind chill") is
considered.[85]

Spring and fall are variable, prone to extremes in temperature and
unpredictable swings in conditions. Hot days above 30 °C (86 °F) have occurred
as early as April[86] or as late as October.[87][85] Annual precipitation
averages around 940 millimetres (37 in).

Ottawa experiences about 2,130 hours of average sunshine annually (46% of
possible). Winds in Ottawa are generally [Westerlies](/wiki/Westerlies
"Westerlies") averaging 13 km/h but tend to be slightly more dominant during
the winter.[85]

The highest temperature ever recorded in Ottawa was 37.8 °C (100 °F) on 4 July
1913, 1 August 1917 and 11 August 1944.[85][88] The coldest temperature ever
recorded was −38.9 °C (−38 °F) on 29 December 1933.[85]

### Neighbourhoods and outlying
communities[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ottawa&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Neighbourhoods and outlying communities")]

Further information: [List of neighbourhoods in
Ottawa](/wiki/List_of_neighbourhoods_in_Ottawa "List of neighbourhoods in
Ottawa")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Newottawamap.png/220px-
Newottawamap.png)](/wiki/File:Newottawamap.png)

[](/wiki/File:Newottawamap.png "Enlarge")

Map of Ottawa showing urban areas and names of historic communities.

Ottawa is bounded on the east by the [United Counties of Prescott and
Russell](/wiki/Prescott_and_Russell_United_Counties,_Ontario "Prescott and
Russell United Counties, Ontario"); by [Renfrew
County](/wiki/Renfrew_County,_Ontario "Renfrew County, Ontario") and [Lanark
County](/wiki/Lanark_County,_Ontario "Lanark County, Ontario") in the west; on
the south by the [United Counties of Leeds and
Grenville](/wiki/Leeds_and_Grenville_United_Counties "Leeds and Grenville
United Counties") and the [United Counties of Stormont, Dundas and
Glengarry](/wiki/Stormont,_Dundas_and_Glengarry_United_Counties,_Ontario
"Stormont, Dundas and Glengarry United Counties, Ontario"); and on the north
by the [Regional County Municipality of Les Collines-
de-l'Outaouais](/wiki/Les_Collines-
de-l%27Outaouais_Regional_County_Municipality,_Quebec "Les Collines-
de-l'Outaouais Regional County Municipality, Quebec") and the City of
Gatineau.[102] Modern Ottawa is made up of eleven historic townships, ten of
which are from [Carleton County](/wiki/Carleton_County,_Ontario "Carleton
County, Ontario") and one from [Russell](/wiki/Russell_County,_Ontario
"Russell County, Ontario").[103]

The city has a main [urban area](/wiki/Urban_area "Urban area") but many other
urban, [suburban](/wiki/Suburb "Suburb") and [rural](/wiki/Rural "Rural")
areas exist within the modern city's limits.[104] The main suburban area
extends a considerable distance to the east, west and south of the
centre,[104] and it includes the former cities of Gloucester,
[Nepean](/wiki/Nepean,_Ontario "Nepean, Ontario") and
[Vanier](/wiki/Vanier,_Ontario "Vanier, Ontario"), the former
[village](/wiki/Village "Village") of [Rockcliffe
Park](/wiki/Rockcliffe_Park,_Ontario "Rockcliffe Park, Ontario") (a high-
income neighbourhood which is adjacent to the Prime Minister's official
residence at 24 Sussex and the Governor General's residence), and the
communities of [Blackburn Hamlet](/wiki/Blackburn_Hamlet,_Ontario "Blackburn
Hamlet, Ontario") and [Orléans](/wiki/Orl%C3%A9ans,_Ontario "Orléans,
Ontario").[105] The [Kanata](/wiki/Kanata,_Ontario "Kanata, Ontario") suburban
area includes the former village of [Stittsville](/wiki/Stittsville,_Ontario
"Stittsville, Ontario") to the southwest.[105] Nepean is another major suburb
which also includes [Barrhaven](/wiki/Barrhaven,_Ontario "Barrhaven,
Ontario").[105] The communities of [Manotick](/wiki/Manotick,_Ontario
"Manotick, Ontario") and [Riverside South](/wiki/Riverside_South,_Ottawa
"Riverside South, Ottawa") are located on the other side of the Rideau River,
and [Greely](/wiki/Greely,_Ontario "Greely, Ontario"), southeast of Riverside
South.[105] A number of rural communities (villages and
[hamlets](/wiki/Hamlet_\(place\) "Hamlet \(place\)")) lie beyond the greenbelt
but are administratively part of the Ottawa municipality.[104] Some of these
communities are [Burritts Rapids](/wiki/Burritts_Rapids,_Ontario "Burritts
Rapids, Ontario"); [Ashton](/wiki/Ashton,_Ontario "Ashton, Ontario");
[Fallowfield](/wiki/Fallowfield,_Ontario "Fallowfield, Ontario");
[Kars](/wiki/Kars,_Ontario "Kars, Ontario"); [Fitzroy
Harbour](/wiki/Fitzroy_Harbour,_Ontario "Fitzroy Harbour, Ontario");
[Munster](/wiki/Munster,_Ontario "Munster, Ontario");
[Carp](/wiki/Carp,_Ontario "Carp, Ontario"); [North
Gower](/wiki/North_Gower,_Ontario "North Gower, Ontario");
[Metcalfe](/wiki/Metcalfe,_Ontario "Metcalfe, Ontario"); [Constance
Bay](/wiki/Constance_Bay,_Ontario "Constance Bay, Ontario") and
[Osgoode](/wiki/Osgoode,_Ontario "Osgoode, Ontario") and
[Richmond](/wiki/Richmond,_Ontario "Richmond, Ontario").[105] Several
[towns](/wiki/Town "Town") are located within the federally defined National
Capital Region but outside the [city of Ottawa](/wiki/City_of_Ottawa "City of
Ottawa") municipal boundaries,[104] these include the urban communities of
[Almonte](/wiki/Almonte,_Ontario "Almonte, Ontario"), [Carleton
Place](/wiki/Carleton_Place,_Ontario "Carleton Place, Ontario"),
[Embrun](/wiki/Embrun,_Ontario "Embrun, Ontario"),
[Kemptville](/wiki/Kemptville,_Ontario "Kemptville, Ontario"),
[Rockland](/wiki/Rockland,_Ontario "Rockland, Ontario"), and
[Russell](/wiki/Russell,_Ontario_\(community\) "Russell, Ontario
\(community\)").[105]

In 2011, the populations of the City of Ottawa and the Ottawa–Gatineau [census
metropolitan area](/wiki/Census_metropolitan_area "Census metropolitan area")
(CMA) were 883,391 and 1,236,324 respectively.[113][114] The city had a
population density of 316.6 persons per km2 in 2006, while the CMA had a
population density of 196.6 persons per km2.[113][114] It is the second-
largest city in Ontario, fourth-largest city in the country, and the fourth-
largest CMA in the country.

Ottawa's median age of 39.2 is both below the provincial and national averages
as of
2011[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Ottawa&action=edit).[113][115][116]
Youths under 15 years constituted 16.8% of the total population as of
2011[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Ottawa&action=edit), while
those of retirement age (65 years and older) made up 13.2%.[113] In 2011,
females made up 51.5% of the amalgamated Ottawa population.[113]

Between 1987 and 2002, 131,816 individuals relocated to the city, which
represents 75% of the population growth for that period.[117] Over 20 percent
of the city's population is foreign-born, with the most common non-Canadian
countries of origin being the United Kingdom (8.8% of those foreign-born),
China (8.0%), and Lebanon (4.8%). About 6.1% of residents are not Canadian
citizens.[118]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Francoottawa.PNG/220px-
Francoottawa.PNG)](/wiki/File:Francoottawa.PNG)

[](/wiki/File:Francoottawa.PNG "Enlarge")

Distribution map from the [2001 census](/wiki/Canada_2001_Census "Canada 2001
Census") showcasing the percentage of individuals whose mother tongue is
[French](/wiki/French_language "French language").

Members of visible minority groups (non-[white](/wiki/White_people "White
people")/[European](/wiki/European_Canadian "European Canadian")) constitute
23.7%, while those of [Aboriginal](/wiki/Aboriginal_peoples_in_Canada
"Aboriginal peoples in Canada") origin make up 2.1% of the total population.
The largest [visible minority](/wiki/Visible_minority "Visible minority")
groups are: [Black Canadians](/wiki/Black_Canadians "Black Canadians"): 5.7%,
[Chinese Canadians](/wiki/Chinese_Canadians "Chinese Canadians"): 4.0%, [South
Asians](/wiki/South_Asian_Canadian "South Asian Canadian"): 3.9%, and
[Arabs](/wiki/Arab_Canadians "Arab Canadians"): 3.7%. Smaller groups include
[Latin Americans](/wiki/Latin_American_Canadian "Latin American Canadian"),
[Southeast Asians](/wiki/Southeast_Asia "Southeast Asia"),
[Filipinos](/wiki/Filipino_Canadian "Filipino Canadian"), and [West
Asians](/wiki/Western_Asia "Western Asia").[118]

Around 65% of Ottawa residents describe themselves as Christian as of
2011[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Ottawa&action=edit), with
[Catholics](/wiki/Catholicism "Catholicism") accounting for 38.5% of the
population and members of [Protestant](/wiki/Protestantism "Protestantism")
churches 25%. Non-Christian religions are also very well established in
Ottawa, the largest being [Islam](/wiki/Islam "Islam") (6.7%),
[Hinduism](/wiki/Hinduism "Hinduism") (1.4%), [Buddhism](/wiki/Buddhism
"Buddhism") (1.3%), and [Judaism](/wiki/Judaism "Judaism") (1.2%). Those with
no religious affiliation represent 22.8%.[118]

[Bilingualism](/wiki/Bilingualism_in_Ottawa "Bilingualism in Ottawa") became
official policy for the conduct of municipal business in 2002,[119] and 37% of
the population can speak both languages as of
2006[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Ottawa&action=edit),[111]
making it the largest city in Canada with both English and French as co-
official languages.[120] Those who identify their mother tongue as
[English](/wiki/English_language "English language") constitute 62.4 percent,
while those with [French](/wiki/French_language "French language") as their
mother tongue make up 14.2 percent of the population. In terms of respondents'
knowledge of one or both official languages, 59.9 percent and 1.5 percent of
the population have knowledge of English only and French only, respectively;
while 37.2 percent have a knowledge of both official languages. The overall
Ottawa–Gatineau census metropolitan area (CMA) has a larger proportion of
French speakers than Ottawa itself, since Gatineau is overwhelmingly French
speaking. An additional 20.4 percent of the population list languages other
than English and French as their mother tongue. These include
[Arabic](/wiki/Arabic_language "Arabic language") (3.2%),
[Chinese](/wiki/Chinese_language "Chinese language") (3.0%),
[Spanish](/wiki/Spanish_language "Spanish language") (1.2%),
[Italian](/wiki/Italian_language "Italian language") (1.1%), and many
others.[118]

## Economy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ottawa&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Economy")]

See also: [Economy of Ontario](/wiki/Economy_of_Ontario "Economy of Ontario")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Tunney%27s_Pasture.jpg/220px-
Tunney%27s_Pasture.jpg)](/wiki/File:Tunney%27s_Pasture.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Tunney%27s_Pasture.jpg "Enlarge")

Developed in the early 1950s, [Tunney's Pasture](/wiki/Tunney%27s_Pasture
"Tunney's Pasture") is an area that holds a number of federal government
buildings. The federal government is the city's largest employer.

Ottawa has a high standard of living, low unemployment,[121][122] and the
fourth highest GDP growth rate among major Canadian cities in 2007 at 2.7%,
which exceeded the Canadian average of 2.4%.[123] The region of Ottawa-
Gatineau has the third highest income of all [major Canadian
cities](/wiki/List_of_cities_in_Canada "List of cities in Canada").[123] The
average gross income in the region amounted to $40,078, an increase of 4.9%
compared to the previous year.[123] The annual cost of living rate in 2007
grew 1.9%.[123] [Mercer](/wiki/Mercer_Human_Resource_Consulting "Mercer Human
Resource Consulting") ranks Ottawa with the third highest [quality of
living](/wiki/Quality_of_Living_Survey "Quality of Living Survey") of any
large city in the Americas, and 16th highest in the world.[124] It is also
rated the second cleanest city in Canada, and third cleanest city in the
world.[125]

Ottawa's primary employers are the [Public Service of
Canada](/wiki/Public_Service_of_Canada "Public Service of Canada") and the
high-tech industry, although tourism and healthcare also represent
increasingly sizeable economic activities. The Federal government is the
city's largest employer, employing over 110,000 individuals from the National
Capital region.[126] The national headquarters for many federal departments
are located in Ottawa, particularly throughout [Centretown](/wiki/Centretown
"Centretown") and in the [Terrasses de la
Chaudière](/wiki/Terrasses_de_la_Chaudi%C3%A8re "Terrasses de la Chaudière")
and [Place du Portage](/wiki/Place_du_Portage "Place du Portage") complexes in
Hull. The [National Defence
Headquarters](/wiki/National_Defence_Headquarters_\(Canada\) "National Defence
Headquarters \(Canada\)") located in Ottawa is the main command centre for the
[Canadian Armed Forces](/wiki/Canadian_Armed_Forces "Canadian Armed Forces")
and hosts the [Department of National
Defence](/wiki/Department_of_National_Defence_\(Canada\) "Department of
National Defence \(Canada\)").[127] The Ottawa area includes [CFS
Leitrim](/wiki/CFS_Leitrim "CFS Leitrim"), [CFB Uplands](/wiki/CFB_Uplands
"CFB Uplands"), and the former [CFB Rockcliffe](/wiki/CFB_Rockcliffe "CFB
Rockcliffe"). During the summer, the city hosts the [Ceremonial
Guard](/wiki/Ceremonial_Guard "Ceremonial Guard"), which performs functions
such as the [Changing the Guard](/wiki/Changing_the_Guard "Changing the
Guard").[128] As the national capital of Canada, tourism is an important part
of Ottawa's economy, particularly after the [150th anniversary of
Canada](/wiki/150th_anniversary_of_Canada "150th anniversary of Canada") which
was centred in Ottawa. The lead-up to the festivities saw much investment in
civic infrastructure, upgrades to tourist infrastructure and increases in
national cultural attractions. The National Capital Region annually attracts
an estimated 7.3 million tourists, who spend about 1.18 billion dollars.[129]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Silicon_valley_north.JPG/220px-
Silicon_valley_north.JPG)](/wiki/File:Silicon_valley_north.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Silicon_valley_north.JPG "Enlarge")

[Kanata Research Park](/wiki/Kanata_Research_Park "Kanata Research Park") is
home to many companies, mostly high-tech industries.

In addition to the economic activities that come with being the national
capital, Ottawa is an important technology centre; in 2015, its 1800 companies
employed approximately 63,400 people.[130] The concentration of companies in
this industry earned the city the nickname of "Silicon Valley North".[65] Most
of these companies specialize in [telecommunications](/wiki/Telecommunications
"Telecommunications"), [software development](/wiki/Software_development
"Software development") and [environmental
technology](/wiki/Environmental_technology "Environmental technology"). Large
technology companies such as Nortel, Corel, Mitel, [Cognos](/wiki/Cognos
"Cognos"), [Halogen Software](/wiki/Halogen_Software "Halogen Software"),
[Shopify](/wiki/Shopify "Shopify") and [JDS Uniphase](/wiki/JDS_Uniphase "JDS
Uniphase") were founded in the city.[131] Ottawa also has regional locations
for [Nokia](/wiki/Nokia "Nokia"), [3M](/wiki/3M "3M"), [Adobe
Systems](/wiki/Adobe_Systems "Adobe Systems"), [Bell Canada](/wiki/Bell_Canada
"Bell Canada"), [IBM](/wiki/IBM "IBM") and [Hewlett-Packard](/wiki/Hewlett-
Packard "Hewlett-Packard").[132] Many of the telecommunications and new
technology are located in the western part of the city (formerly Kanata). The
"tech sector" was doing particularly well in 2015/2016.[133][117]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Cheo3.jpg/220px-
Cheo3.jpg)](/wiki/File:Cheo3.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Cheo3.jpg "Enlarge")

The [Children's Hospital of Eastern Ontario
(CHEO)](/wiki/Children%27s_Hospital_of_Eastern_Ontario "Children's Hospital of
Eastern Ontario") is a major [children's](/wiki/Children%27s_hospital
"Children's hospital") and [teaching hospital](/wiki/Teaching_hospital
"Teaching hospital"). The health sector is another major employer in Ottawa.

Another major employer is the health sector, which employs over 18,000
people.[134] Four active general hospitals are in the Ottawa area: [Queensway-
Carleton Hospital](/wiki/Queensway-Carleton_Hospital "Queensway-Carleton
Hospital"), [The Ottawa Hospital](/wiki/The_Ottawa_Hospital "The Ottawa
Hospital"), [Montfort Hospital](/wiki/Montfort_Hospital "Montfort Hospital"),
and [Children's Hospital of Eastern
Ontario](/wiki/Children%27s_Hospital_of_Eastern_Ontario "Children's Hospital
of Eastern Ontario"). Several specialized hospital facilities are also
present, such as the [University of Ottawa Heart
Institute](/wiki/University_of_Ottawa_Heart_Institute "University of Ottawa
Heart Institute") and the [Royal Ottawa Mental Health
Centre](/wiki/Royal_Ottawa_Mental_Health_Centre "Royal Ottawa Mental Health
Centre").[135] [Nordion](/wiki/Nordion "Nordion"), [i-Stat](/wiki/I-Stat
"I-Stat") and the National Research Council of Canada and [OHRI](/wiki/OHRI
"OHRI") are part of the growing life science sector.[136][137] Business,
finance, administration, and sales and service rank high among types of
occupations.[111] Approximately ten percent of Ottawa's GDP is derived from
finance, insurance and real estate whereas employment in goods-producing
industries is only half the national average.[138] The City of Ottawa is the
second largest employer[139][140] with over 15,000 employees.[140][141]

In 2006, Ottawa experienced an increase of 40,000 jobs over 2001 with a five-
year average growth that was relatively slower than in the late 1990s.[123]
While the number of employees in the federal government stagnated, the high-
technology industry grew by 2.4%. The overall growth of jobs in Ottawa-
Gatineau was 1.3% compared to the previous year, down to sixth place among
Canada's largest cities.[123] The unemployment rate in Ottawa-Gatineau was
5.2% (only in Ottawa: 5.1%),[142] which was below the national average of
6.0%.[123] The economic downturn resulted in an increase in the unemployment
rate between April 2008 and April 2009 from 4.7 to 6.3%. In the province,
however, this rate increased over the same period from 6.4 to 9.1%.[143]

## Culture[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ottawa&action=edit&section=7 "Edit
section: Culture")]

See also: [List of festivals in Ottawa](/wiki/List_of_festivals_in_Ottawa
"List of festivals in Ottawa")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/Byward_District_in_Ottawa.jpg/220px-
Byward_District_in_Ottawa.jpg)](/wiki/File:Byward_District_in_Ottawa.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Byward_District_in_Ottawa.jpg "Enlarge")

[Byward Market](/wiki/Byward_Market "Byward Market") has been a focal point
for culture in Ottawa.

Traditionally the [ByWard Market](/wiki/ByWard_Market "ByWard Market") (in
Lower Town), Parliament Hill and the [Golden
Triangle](/wiki/Golden_Triangle_\(Ottawa,_Canada\) "Golden Triangle \(Ottawa,
Canada\)") (both in Centretown – Downtown) have been the focal points of the
cultural scenes in Ottawa.[144] Modern thoroughfares such as [Wellington
Street](/wiki/Wellington_Street_\(Ottawa\) "Wellington Street \(Ottawa\)"),
[Rideau Street](/wiki/Rideau_Street "Rideau Street"), [Sussex
Drive](/wiki/Sussex_Drive "Sussex Drive"), [Elgin
Street](/wiki/Elgin_Street_\(Ottawa\) "Elgin Street \(Ottawa\)"), [Bank
Street](/wiki/Bank_Street_\(Ottawa\) "Bank Street \(Ottawa\)"), [Somerset
Street](/wiki/Somerset_Street_\(Ottawa\) "Somerset Street \(Ottawa\)"),
[Preston Street](/wiki/Preston_Street_\(Ottawa\) "Preston Street \(Ottawa\)"),
Richmond Road in Westboro, and Sparks Street are home to many boutiques,
museums, theatres, galleries, landmarks and memorials in addition to eating
establishments, cafes, bars and nightclubs.[145]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Ice_slide_Winterlude_Ottawa_2007.jpg/220px-
Ice_slide_Winterlude_Ottawa_2007.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ice_slide_Winterlude_Ottawa_2007.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Ice_slide_Winterlude_Ottawa_2007.jpg "Enlarge")

People on ice slides during [Winterlude](/wiki/Winterlude "Winterlude"), an
annual [winter festival](/wiki/Winter_festival "Winter festival") held in
Ottawa.

Ottawa hosts a variety of annual seasonal activities—such as
[Winterlude](/wiki/Winterlude "Winterlude"), the largest festival in
Canada,[146] and [Canada Day](/wiki/Canada_Day "Canada Day") celebrations on
Parliament Hill and surrounding downtown area, as well as
[Bluesfest](/wiki/Ottawa_Bluesfest "Ottawa Bluesfest"), [Canadian Tulip
Festival](/wiki/Canadian_Tulip_Festival "Canadian Tulip Festival"), [Ottawa
Dragon Boat Festival](/wiki/Ottawa_Dragon_Boat_Festival "Ottawa Dragon Boat
Festival"), [Ottawa International Jazz
Festival](/wiki/Ottawa_International_Jazz_Festival "Ottawa International Jazz
Festival"), [Fringe Festival](/wiki/Ottawa_Fringe_Festival "Ottawa Fringe
Festival") and [Folk Music Festival](/wiki/Ottawa_Folk_Festival "Ottawa Folk
Festival"), that have grown to become some of the largest festivals of their
kind in the world.[147][148] In 2010, Ottawa's Festival industry received the
[IFEA](/wiki/International_Festivals_and_Events_Association "International
Festivals and Events Association") "World Festival and Event City Award" for
the category of North American cities with a population between 500,000 and
1,000,000.[149]

As Canada's capital, Ottawa has played host to a number of significant
cultural events in [Canadian history](/wiki/Canadian_history "Canadian
history"), including the first visit of the reigning [Canadian
sovereign](/wiki/Monarchy_of_Canada "Monarchy of Canada")—[King George
VI](/wiki/George_VI "George VI"), with [his
consort](/wiki/List_of_royal_consorts_of_Canada "List of royal consorts of
Canada"), [Queen Elizabeth](/wiki/Queen_Elizabeth_The_Queen_Mother "Queen
Elizabeth The Queen Mother")—[to his parliament, on 19 May
1939](/wiki/1939_royal_tour_of_Canada "1939 royal tour of Canada").[150] [VE
Day](/wiki/Victory_in_Europe_Day "Victory in Europe Day") was marked with a
large celebration on 8 May 1945,[151] the first raising of [the country's new
national flag](/wiki/Flag_of_Canada "Flag of Canada") took place on 15
February 1965,[152] and the [centennial of
Confederation](/wiki/Canadian_Centennial "Canadian Centennial") was celebrated
on 1 July 1967.[153] [Elizabeth II](/wiki/Elizabeth_II "Elizabeth II") was in
Ottawa on 17 April 1982, to issue a [royal proclamation](/wiki/Proclamation
"Proclamation") of the enactment of the [Constitution
Act](/wiki/Constitution_Act,_1982 "Constitution Act, 1982").[154] In 1983,
[Prince Charles](/wiki/Prince_Charles "Prince Charles") and [Diana Princess of
Wales](/wiki/Diana_Princess_of_Wales "Diana Princess of Wales") came to Ottawa
for a state dinner hosted by then Prime Minister [Pierre
Trudeau](/wiki/Pierre_Trudeau "Pierre Trudeau").[155] In 2011, Ottawa was
selected as the first city to receive [Prince William, Duke of
Cambridge](/wiki/Prince_William,_Duke_of_Cambridge "Prince William, Duke of
Cambridge"), and [Catherine, Duchess of
Cambridge](/wiki/Catherine,_Duchess_of_Cambridge "Catherine, Duchess of
Cambridge") during their [tour of Canada](/wiki/2011_royal_tour_of_Canada
"2011 royal tour of Canada").

### Architecture[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ottawa&action=edit&section=8 "Edit
section: Architecture")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Connaught_Building_%2814579938218%29.jpg/220px-
Connaught_Building_%2814579938218%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Connaught_Building_\(14579938218\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Connaught_Building_\(14579938218\).jpg "Enlarge")

Completed in 1913, the [Connaught Building](/wiki/Connaught_Building
"Connaught Building"), was constructed in a Gothic Revival style. In the
following decades, buildings built for the government would abandon the style,
in favour of [formal](/wiki/Formalism_\(art\) "Formalism \(art\)") and
[functional](/wiki/Functionalism_\(architecture\) "Functionalism
\(architecture\)") styles.

Main article: [Architecture of Ottawa](/wiki/Architecture_of_Ottawa
"Architecture of Ottawa")

Influenced by government structures, much of the city's architecture tends to
be [formalistic](/wiki/Formalism_\(art\) "Formalism \(art\)") and
[functional](/wiki/Functionalism_\(architecture\) "Functionalism
\(architecture\)"); however, the city is also marked by
[Romantic](/wiki/Romanticism "Romanticism") and
[Picturesque](/wiki/Picturesque "Picturesque") styles of architecture such as
the Parliament Buildings' gothic revival architecture.[156] Ottawa's domestic
architecture is dominated by single family homes, but also includes smaller
numbers of [semi-detached](/wiki/Semi-detached "Semi-detached") houses,
[rowhouses](/wiki/Rowhouse "Rowhouse"), and [apartment
buildings](/wiki/Apartment_building "Apartment building"). Many domestic
buildings are clad in brick, with small numbers covered in wood, stone, or
siding of different materials; variations are common, depending on
neighbourhoods and the age of dwellings within them.

The [skyline](/wiki/Skyline "Skyline") has been controlled by building height
restrictions originally implemented to keep Parliament Hill and the Peace
Tower at 92.2 metres (302 ft) visible from most parts of the city.[157] Today,
[several buildings are slightly
taller](/wiki/List_of_tallest_buildings_in_Ottawa-Gatineau "List of tallest
buildings in Ottawa-Gatineau") than the Peace Tower, with the tallest located
on [Albert Street](/wiki/Albert_Street_\(Ottawa\) "Albert Street \(Ottawa\)")
being the 29-storey [Place de Ville](/wiki/Place_de_Ville "Place de Ville")
(Tower C) at 112 metres (367 ft).[158] Federal buildings in the National
Capital Region are managed by [Public Works
Canada](/wiki/Public_Works_and_Government_Services_Canada "Public Works and
Government Services Canada"), while most of the federal land in the region is
managed by the National Capital Commission; its control of much undeveloped
land gives the NCC a great deal of influence over the city's development.[159]

### Museums and performing
arts[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ottawa&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section:
Museums and performing arts")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/CanadianMuseumofNature2010-05-19.JPG/220px-
CanadianMuseumofNature2010-05-19.JPG)](/wiki/File:CanadianMuseumofNature2010-05-19.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:CanadianMuseumofNature2010-05-19.JPG "Enlarge")

The [Canadian Museum of Nature](/wiki/Canadian_Museum_of_Nature "Canadian
Museum of Nature") is a [natural history](/wiki/Natural_history "Natural
history") and [natural science](/wiki/Natural_science "Natural science")
museum. The institution is one of several national museums located in Ottawa.

Further information: [List of attractions in
Ottawa](/wiki/List_of_attractions_in_Ottawa "List of attractions in Ottawa")

Amongst the city's national museums and galleries is the [National Gallery of
Canada](/wiki/National_Gallery_of_Canada "National Gallery of Canada");
designed by famous architect [Moshe Safdie](/wiki/Moshe_Safdie "Moshe
Safdie"), it is a permanent home to the [Maman](/wiki/Maman_\(sculpture\)
"Maman \(sculpture\)") sculpture.[160] The [Canadian War
Museum](/wiki/Canadian_War_Museum "Canadian War Museum") houses over 3.75
million artifacts and was moved to an expanded facility in 2005.[161] The
[Canadian Museum of Nature](/wiki/Canadian_Museum_of_Nature "Canadian Museum
of Nature") was built in 1905, and underwent a major renovation between 2004
and 2010.[162] Across the Ottawa river in Gatineau is the most visited [museum
in Canada](/wiki/List_of_museums_in_Canada "List of museums in Canada"), the
[Canadian Museum of History](/wiki/Canadian_Museum_of_History "Canadian Museum
of History").[163] Designed by Canadian Aboriginal architect [Douglas
Cardinal](/wiki/Douglas_Cardinal "Douglas Cardinal"), the curving-shaped
complex, built at a cost of 340 million USD, also houses the [Canadian
Children's Museum](/wiki/Canadian_Children%27s_Museum "Canadian Children's
Museum"), the [Canadian Postal Museum](/wiki/Canadian_Postal_Museum "Canadian
Postal Museum") and a 3D [IMAX](/wiki/IMAX "IMAX") theatre.[164]

The city is also home to the [Canada Agriculture
Museum](/wiki/Canada_Agriculture_Museum "Canada Agriculture Museum"), the
[Canada Aviation and Space Museum](/wiki/Canada_Aviation_and_Space_Museum
"Canada Aviation and Space Museum"), the [Canada Science and Technology
Museum](/wiki/Canada_Science_and_Technology_Museum "Canada Science and
Technology Museum"), [Billings Estate Museum](/wiki/Billings_Estate_Museum
"Billings Estate Museum"), [Bytown Museum](/wiki/Bytown_Museum "Bytown
Museum"), [Canadian Museum of Contemporary
Photography](/wiki/Canadian_Museum_of_Contemporary_Photography "Canadian
Museum of Contemporary Photography"), the [Bank of Canada
Museum](/wiki/The_Bank_of_Canada_Museum "The Bank of Canada Museum"), and the
[Portrait Gallery of Canada](/wiki/Portrait_Gallery_of_Canada "Portrait
Gallery of Canada").[165]

The [Ottawa Little Theatre](/wiki/Ottawa_Little_Theatre "Ottawa Little
Theatre"), originally called the Ottawa Drama League at its inception in 1913,
is the longest-running community theatre company in Ottawa.[166] Since 1969,
Ottawa has been the home of the [National Arts
Centre](/wiki/National_Arts_Centre "National Arts Centre"), a major performing
arts venue that houses four stages and is home to the [National Arts Centre
Orchestra](/wiki/National_Arts_Centre_Orchestra "National Arts Centre
Orchestra"), the [Ottawa Symphony Orchestra](/wiki/Ottawa_Symphony_Orchestra
"Ottawa Symphony Orchestra") and [Opera Lyra Ottawa](/wiki/Opera_Lyra_Ottawa
"Opera Lyra Ottawa").[167] Established in 1975, the [Great Canadian Theatre
Company](/wiki/Great_Canadian_Theatre_Company "Great Canadian Theatre
Company") specializes in the production of Canadian plays at a local
level.[168]

### Historic and heritage
sites[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ottawa&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section:
Historic and heritage sites")]

[![The National War Memorial and Château
Laurier](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/National_War_Memorial%2C_Ottawa%2C_ON.jpg/220px-
National_War_Memorial%2C_Ottawa%2C_ON.jpg)](/wiki/File:National_War_Memorial,_Ottawa,_ON.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:National_War_Memorial,_Ottawa,_ON.jpg "Enlarge")

The [National War Memorial](/wiki/National_War_Memorial_\(Canada\) "National
War Memorial \(Canada\)") and [Château Laurier](/wiki/Ch%C3%A2teau_Laurier
"Château Laurier") are both designated as [National Historic Site of
Canada](/wiki/National_Historic_Sites_of_Canada "National Historic Sites of
Canada")

Main articles: [List of National Historic Sites of Canada in
Ottawa](/wiki/List_of_National_Historic_Sites_of_Canada_in_Ottawa "List of
National Historic Sites of Canada in Ottawa") and [List of designated heritage
properties in Ottawa](/wiki/List_of_designated_heritage_properties_in_Ottawa
"List of designated heritage properties in Ottawa")

The [Rideau Canal](/wiki/Rideau_Canal "Rideau Canal") is the oldest
continuously operated canal system in North America, and in 2007, it was
registered as a UNESCO World Heritage Site.[169] In addition, 24 other
National Historic Sites of Canada are in Ottawa, including: the [Central
Chambers](/wiki/Central_Chambers_\(Ottawa\) "Central Chambers \(Ottawa\)"),
the [Central Experimental Farm](/wiki/Central_Experimental_Farm "Central
Experimental Farm"), the [Château Laurier](/wiki/Ch%C3%A2teau_Laurier "Château
Laurier"), Confederation Square, the [former Ottawa Teachers'
College](/wiki/Ottawa_Normal_School "Ottawa Normal School"), [Office of the
Prime Minister and Privy
Council](/wiki/Office_of_the_Prime_Minister_and_Privy_Council "Office of the
Prime Minister and Privy Council"), [Laurier House](/wiki/Laurier_House
"Laurier House") and the Parliament Buildings. Many other properties of
cultural value have been designated as having "heritage elements" by the City
of Ottawa under Part IV of the [Ontario Heritage
Act](/wiki/Ontario_Heritage_Act "Ontario Heritage Act").[170]

### Sports[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ottawa&action=edit&section=11 "Edit
section: Sports")]

Further information: [Sport in Ottawa](/wiki/Sport_in_Ottawa "Sport in
Ottawa") and [List of Ottawa parks](/wiki/List_of_Ottawa_parks "List of Ottawa
parks")

[Sport in Ottawa](/wiki/Sport_in_Ottawa "Sport in Ottawa") has a history
dating back to the 19th century. Ottawa is currently home to four professional
sports teams. The [Ottawa Senators](/wiki/Ottawa_Senators "Ottawa Senators")
are a professional ice hockey team playing in the [National Hockey
League](/wiki/National_Hockey_League "National Hockey League"). The Senators
play their home games at the [Canadian Tire Centre](/wiki/Canadian_Tire_Centre
"Canadian Tire Centre").[171] The [Ottawa Redblacks](/wiki/Ottawa_Redblacks
"Ottawa Redblacks") are a professional Canadian Football team playing in the
[Canadian Football League](/wiki/Canadian_Football_League "Canadian Football
League").[172] Professional soccer club [Ottawa Fury FC](/wiki/Ottawa_Fury_FC
"Ottawa Fury FC") play in the [United Soccer
League](/wiki/United_Soccer_League "United Soccer League"), the second
division in North American pro soccer after [Major League
Soccer](/wiki/Major_League_Soccer "Major League Soccer"). Both Ottawa Fury FC
and the Ottawa Redblacks play their home games at [TD Place
Stadium](/wiki/TD_Place_Stadium "TD Place Stadium"). The [Ottawa
Champions](/wiki/Ottawa_Champions "Ottawa Champions") play professional
baseball in the [Can-Am
League](/wiki/Canadian_American_Association_of_Professional_Baseball "Canadian
American Association of Professional Baseball") at [Raymond Chabot Grant
Thornton Park](/wiki/Raymond_Chabot_Grant_Thornton_Park "Raymond Chabot Grant
Thornton Park"), following the departure of the Lynx International League
franchise. Several non-professional teams also play in Ottawa, including the
[Ottawa 67's](/wiki/Ottawa_67%27s "Ottawa 67's") [junior ice
hockey](/wiki/Junior_ice_hockey "Junior ice hockey") team.[173] The city was
previously home to a professional basketball team, the [Ottawa
SkyHawks](/wiki/Ottawa_SkyHawks "Ottawa SkyHawks"), of the [National
Basketball League of Canada](/wiki/National_Basketball_League_of_Canada
"National Basketball League of Canada")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/TD_Place_Stadium_Summer_2014.jpg/220px-
TD_Place_Stadium_Summer_2014.jpg)](/wiki/File:TD_Place_Stadium_Summer_2014.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:TD_Place_Stadium_Summer_2014.jpg "Enlarge")

[TD Place Stadium](/wiki/TD_Place_Stadium "TD Place Stadium") is an outdoor
stadium and is home to the [CFL](/wiki/Canadian_Football_League "Canadian
Football League")'s [Ottawa Redblacks](/wiki/Ottawa_Redblacks "Ottawa
Redblacks") and the [USL](/wiki/United_Soccer_League "United Soccer League")'s
[Ottawa Fury FC](/wiki/Ottawa_Fury_FC "Ottawa Fury FC").

Collegiate teams in various sports compete in [Canadian Interuniversity
Sport](/wiki/Canadian_Interuniversity_Sport "Canadian Interuniversity Sport").
The [Carleton Ravens](/wiki/Carleton_Ravens "Carleton Ravens") are nationally
ranked in [basketball](/wiki/Basketball "Basketball"),[174] and the [Ottawa
Gee-Gees](/wiki/Ottawa_Gee-Gees "Ottawa Gee-Gees") are nationally ranked in
[football](/wiki/Canadian_football "Canadian football") and basketball.
Algonquin College has also won numerous national championships. The city is
home to an assortment of amateur organized team sports such as
[soccer](/wiki/Soccer "Soccer"), basketball, [baseball](/wiki/Baseball
"Baseball"), [curling](/wiki/Curling "Curling"), [rowing](/wiki/Rowing
"Rowing"), [hurling](/wiki/Hurling "Hurling") and [horse
racing](/wiki/Horse_racing "Horse racing").[175] Casual recreational
activities, such as [skating](/wiki/Ice_skating "Ice skating"),
[cycling](/wiki/Cycling "Cycling"), [hiking](/wiki/Hiking "Hiking"),
[sailing](/wiki/Sailing "Sailing"), [golfing](/wiki/Golfing "Golfing"),
[skiing](/wiki/Skiing "Skiing"), and [fishing](/wiki/Fishing "Fishing")/[ice
fishing](/wiki/Ice_fishing "Ice fishing") are also popular.[175]
