## Government[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ottawa&action=edit&section=13 "Edit
section: Government")]

Further information: [List of Ottawa municipal
elections](/wiki/List_of_Ottawa_municipal_elections "List of Ottawa municipal
elections"), [Canadian federal election results in
Ottawa](/wiki/Canadian_federal_election_results_in_Ottawa "Canadian federal
election results in Ottawa"), and [List of embassies and high commissions in
Ottawa](/wiki/List_of_embassies_and_high_commissions_in_Ottawa "List of
embassies and high commissions in Ottawa")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/Ottawa_City_Hall_-
_H%C3%B4tel_de_ville_d%27Ottawa.jpg/220px-Ottawa_City_Hall_-
_H%C3%B4tel_de_ville_d%27Ottawa.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ottawa_City_Hall_-
_H%C3%B4tel_de_ville_d%27Ottawa.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Ottawa_City_Hall_-_H%C3%B4tel_de_ville_d%27Ottawa.jpg "Enlarge")

[Ottawa City Hall](/wiki/Ottawa_City_Hall "Ottawa City Hall") houses the [seat
of local government](/wiki/Ottawa_City_Council "Ottawa City Council").

The City of Ottawa is a [single-tier
municipality](/wiki/Census_divisions_of_Ontario#Single-tier_municipalities
"Census divisions of Ontario"), meaning it is in itself a [census
division](/wiki/Census_division "Census division") and has no county or
regional municipality government above it.[176] As a single-tier municipality,
Ottawa has responsibility for all municipal services, including
[fire](/wiki/Ottawa_Fire_Services "Ottawa Fire Services"), [emergency medical
services](/wiki/Ottawa_Paramedic_Service "Ottawa Paramedic Service"),
[police](/wiki/Ottawa_Police_Service "Ottawa Police Service"),
[parks](/wiki/List_of_Ottawa_parks "List of Ottawa parks"),
[roads](/wiki/List_of_numbered_roads_in_Ottawa "List of numbered roads in
Ottawa"), sidewalks, [public transit](/wiki/OC_Transpo "OC Transpo"), drinking
water, storm water, sanitary sewage and solid waste. Ottawa is governed by the
24-member [Ottawa City Council](/wiki/Ottawa_City_Council "Ottawa City
Council") consisting of 23 councillors each representing one
[ward](/wiki/Ward_\(country_subdivision\) "Ward \(country subdivision\)") and
the mayor, currently Jim Watson,[177] elected in a citywide vote.

Along with being the capital of Canada, Ottawa is politically diverse in local
politics. Most of the city has traditionally supported the [Liberal
Party](/wiki/Liberal_Party_of_Canada "Liberal Party of Canada").[178] Perhaps
the safest areas for the Liberals are the ones dominated by
[Francophones](/wiki/Francophones "Francophones"), especially in Vanier and
central Gloucester.[178] Central Ottawa is usually more [left](/wiki/Left-
wing_politics "Left-wing politics")-leaning, and the [New Democratic
Party](/wiki/New_Democratic_Party_\(Canada\) "New Democratic Party
\(Canada\)") have won ridings there. Some of Ottawa's suburbs are swing areas,
notably central Nepean and, despite its francophone population, Orléans.[178]
The southern and western parts of the old city of Ottawa are generally
moderate and swing to the [Conservative
Party](/wiki/Conservative_Party_of_Canada "Conservative Party of
Canada").[178] The farther one goes outside the city centre like to Kanata and
Barrhaven and rural areas, the voters tend to be increasingly conservative,
both fiscally and socially.[178] This is especially true in the former
Townships of [West Carleton](/wiki/West_Carleton_Township,_Ontario "West
Carleton Township, Ontario"), [Goulbourn](/wiki/Goulbourn_Township,_Ontario
"Goulbourn Township, Ontario"), [Rideau](/wiki/Rideau_Township,_Ontario
"Rideau Township, Ontario") and [Osgoode](/wiki/Osgoode_Township,_Ontario
"Osgoode Township, Ontario"), which are more in line with the conservative
areas in the surrounding [counties](/wiki/County "County").[178] However, not
all rural areas support the Conservative Party. Rural parts of the former
township of [Cumberland](/wiki/Cumberland_Township,_Ontario "Cumberland
Township, Ontario"), with a large number of Francophones, traditionally
support the Liberal Party, though their support has recently weakened.[178]

At present, Ottawa is host to [130
embassies](/wiki/List_of_diplomatic_missions_in_Canada "List of diplomatic
missions in Canada").[179] A further 49 countries accredit their [embassies
and missions in the United
States](/wiki/List_of_diplomatic_missions_in_Canada#Accredited_Embassies "List
of diplomatic missions in Canada") to Canada.[179]

## Transportation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ottawa&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Transportation")]

See also: [OC Transpo](/wiki/OC_Transpo "OC Transpo"), [List of airports in
the Ottawa area](/wiki/List_of_airports_in_the_Ottawa_area "List of airports
in the Ottawa area"), [List of Ottawa roads](/wiki/List_of_Ottawa_roads "List
of Ottawa roads"), [List of numbered roads in
Ottawa](/wiki/List_of_numbered_roads_in_Ottawa "List of numbered roads in
Ottawa"), and [List of bridges in Ottawa](/wiki/List_of_bridges_in_Ottawa
"List of bridges in Ottawa")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/O_Train_15773300606.jpg/220px-
O_Train_15773300606.jpg)](/wiki/File:O_Train_15773300606.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:O_Train_15773300606.jpg "Enlarge")

An [O-Train](/wiki/O-Train "O-Train") crossing the [Rideau
River](/wiki/Rideau_River "Rideau River"). The O-Train is a [light
rail](/wiki/Light_rail "Light rail") [public
transportation](/wiki/Public_transportation "Public transportation") service
provided by [OC Transpo](/wiki/OC_Transpo "OC Transpo").

Ottawa is served by a number of [airlines](/wiki/Airlines "Airlines") that fly
into the [Ottawa Macdonald–Cartier International
Airport](/wiki/Ottawa_Macdonald%E2%80%93Cartier_International_Airport "Ottawa
Macdonald–Cartier International Airport"), as well as two main regional
airports [Gatineau-Ottawa Executive Airport](/wiki/Gatineau-
Ottawa_Executive_Airport "Gatineau-Ottawa Executive Airport"), and
[Ottawa/Carp Airport](/wiki/Ottawa/Carp_Airport "Ottawa/Carp Airport").[180]
The city is also served by inter-city passenger rail service at the [Ottawa
Train Station](/wiki/Ottawa_Train_Station "Ottawa Train Station") by [Via
Rail](/wiki/Via_Rail "Via Rail"), located near the Alta Vista neighbourhood,
and inter-city bus service operating out of the [Ottawa Bus Central
Station](/wiki/Ottawa_Bus_Central_Station "Ottawa Bus Central Station").[180]

[OC Transpo](/wiki/OC_Transpo "OC Transpo"), a department of the city,
operates the public transit system.[181] An integrated [hub-and-
spoke](/wiki/Hub-and-spoke "Hub-and-spoke") system of services consists of:
regular buses traveling on fixed routes in mixed traffic, typical of most
urban transit systems;[181] a [bus rapid transit](/wiki/Bus_rapid_transit "Bus
rapid transit") (BRT) system which is a high-frequency bus service operating
on the transitway (a network of mostly grade-separated dedicated bus lanes
within their own right of way) and having full stations with Park & Ride
facilities, further supported by on-road reserved bus lanes and priority
traffic signal controls; a [light rail](/wiki/Light_rail "Light rail") transit
(LRT) system known as the _O-Train_ operating on one north-south route (the
Trillium Line);[181] and a door-to-door bus service for the disabled known as
ParaTranspo.[181] Both OC Transpo and the Quebec-based _[Société de transport
de l'Outaouais](/wiki/Soci%C3%A9t%C3%A9_de_transport_de_l%27Outaouais "Société
de transport de l'Outaouais") (STO)_ operate bus services between Ottawa and
Gatineau.

Construction is underway on the Confederation Line, a 12.5-kilometre (7.8 mi)
light-rail transit line (LRT), which includes a 2.5-kilometre (1.6 mi) tunnel
through the downtown area featuring three underground stations. The project
broke ground in 2013, with operation scheduled to start in 2018.[182][183] A
further 30 kilometers and 19 stations will be built by 2023, referred to as
the Stage 2 plan.[184]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Canal_Rideau_-_007.jpg/220px-
Canal_Rideau_-_007.jpg)](/wiki/File:Canal_Rideau_-_007.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Canal_Rideau_-_007.jpg "Enlarge")

The [Capital Pathway](/wiki/Capital_Pathway "Capital Pathway") is a multi-use
[trail](/wiki/Trail "Trail") interlinking many parks, waterways, and sites
throughout the [National Capital Region](/wiki/National_Capital_Region
"National Capital Region")

The city is served by two freeway corridors. The primary corridor is east-west
and consists of provincial [Highway 417](/wiki/Ontario_Highway_417 "Ontario
Highway 417") (designated as The Queensway) and Ottawa-Carleton [Regional Road
174](/wiki/Regional_Road_174 "Regional Road 174") (formerly Provincial Highway
17); a north-south corridor, [Highway 416](/wiki/Ontario_Highway_416 "Ontario
Highway 416") (designated as Veterans' Memorial Highway), connects Ottawa to
the rest of the [400-Series Highway](/wiki/400-series_highways_\(Ontario\)
"400-series highways \(Ontario\)") network in Ontario at the 401. Highway 417
is also the Ottawa portion of the [Trans-Canada Highway](/wiki/Trans-
Canada_Highway "Trans-Canada Highway"). The city also has several scenic
parkways (promenades), such as [Colonel By Drive](/wiki/Colonel_By_Drive
"Colonel By Drive"), [Queen Elizabeth Driveway](/wiki/Queen_Elizabeth_Driveway
"Queen Elizabeth Driveway"), the Sir John A. Macdonald Parkway, [Rockcliffe
Parkway](/wiki/Rockcliffe_Parkway "Rockcliffe Parkway") and the [Aviation
Parkway](/wiki/Aviation_Parkway_\(Ottawa\) "Aviation Parkway \(Ottawa\)") and
has a freeway connection to [Autoroute 5](/wiki/Quebec_Autoroute_5 "Quebec
Autoroute 5") and [Autoroute 50](/wiki/Quebec_Autoroute_50 "Quebec Autoroute
50"), in Gatineau. In 2006, the National Capital Commission completed
aesthetic enhancements to [Confederation
Boulevard](/wiki/Confederation_Boulevard "Confederation Boulevard"), a
ceremonial route of existing roads linking key attractions on both sides of
the Ottawa River.[185]

Numerous paved [multi-use trails](/wiki/Multi-use_trail "Multi-use trail")
wind their way through much of the city, including along the Ottawa River,
Rideau River, and Rideau Canal. [These pathways](/wiki/Capital_Pathway
"Capital Pathway") are used for transportation, tourism, and recreation.
Because many streets either have wide curb lanes or bicycle lanes, cycling is
a popular mode of transportation throughout the year.[186] As of 31 December
2015, 900 km of cycling facilities are found in Ottawa, including 435 km of
multi use pathways, 8 km of cycle tracks, 200 km of on-road bicycle lanes, and
257 km of paved shoulders.[187] 204 km of new cycling facilities were added
between 2011 and 2014.[187] A downtown street that is restricted to
pedestrians only, [Sparks Street](/wiki/Sparks_Street "Sparks Street") was
turned into a pedestrian mall in 1966.[188] On Sundays (since 1960) and
selected holidays and events additional avenues and streets are reserved for
pedestrian and/or bicycle uses only.[189] In May 2011, The NCC introduced the
[Capital Bixi](/wiki/Capital_Bixi "Capital Bixi") [bicycle-sharing
system](/wiki/Bicycle-sharing_system "Bicycle-sharing system").[190]

## Education[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ottawa&action=edit&section=15 "Edit
section: Education")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Tabaret_Hall_Ottawa_2014.jpg/220px-
Tabaret_Hall_Ottawa_2014.jpg)](/wiki/File:Tabaret_Hall_Ottawa_2014.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Tabaret_Hall_Ottawa_2014.jpg "Enlarge")

Established in 1848, the [University of Ottawa](/wiki/University_of_Ottawa
"University of Ottawa") is the oldest post-secondary institution in the city.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/La_Cit%C3%A9_coll%C3%A9giale_Ottawa_Canada_November_2006.jpg/220px-
La_Cit%C3%A9_coll%C3%A9giale_Ottawa_Canada_November_2006.jpg)](/wiki/File:La_Cit%C3%A9_coll%C3%A9giale_Ottawa_Canada_November_2006.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:La_Cit%C3%A9_coll%C3%A9giale_Ottawa_Canada_November_2006.jpg
"Enlarge")

[La Cité collégiale](/wiki/La_Cit%C3%A9_coll%C3%A9giale "La Cité collégiale")
is the largest French-language college in [Ontario](/wiki/Ontario "Ontario").

Further information: [List of schools in
Ottawa](/wiki/List_of_schools_in_Ottawa "List of schools in Ottawa")

Ottawa is known as one of the most educated cities in Canada, with over half
the population having graduated from college and/or university.[191] Ottawa
has the highest per capita concentration of [engineers](/wiki/Engineer
"Engineer"), [scientists](/wiki/Scientist "Scientist"), and residents with
[PhDs](/wiki/PhD "PhD") in Canada.[192]

The city has two main public universities:

  * The [University of Ottawa](/wiki/University_of_Ottawa "University of Ottawa") (originally named the "College of Bytown") was the first post-secondary institution established in the city in 1848. The university would eventually expand to become the largest English-French bilingual university in the world.[193] It is also a member of the [U15](/wiki/U15_\(universities\) "U15 \(universities\)"), a group of highly respected research-intensive universities in Canada.[194] The university's campus is located in the [Sandy Hill](/wiki/Sandy_Hill,_Ottawa "Sandy Hill, Ottawa") neighbourhood, just adjacent to the city's downtown core.
  * [Carleton University](/wiki/Carleton_University "Carleton University") was founded in 1942 to meet the needs of returning World War II veterans and later became Ontario's first private, non-denominational college. Over time, Carleton would make the transition to the public university that it is today. In recent years, Carleton has become ranked highly among comprehensive universities in Canada.[195] The university's campus sits between [Old Ottawa South](/wiki/Old_Ottawa_South "Old Ottawa South") and Dow's Lake.

Ottawa also has two main public colleges – [Algonquin
College](/wiki/Algonquin_College "Algonquin College") and [La Cité
collégiale](/wiki/La_Cit%C3%A9_coll%C3%A9giale "La Cité collégiale"). It also
has two Catholic universities – [Dominican University
College](/wiki/Dominican_University_College "Dominican University College")
and [Saint Paul University](/wiki/Saint_Paul_University "Saint Paul
University"). Other colleges and universities in nearby areas (namely, the
neighbouring city of Gatineau) include the [University of Quebec en
Outaouais](/wiki/Universit%C3%A9_du_Qu%C3%A9bec_en_Outaouais "Université du
Québec en Outaouais"), [Cégep de
l'Outaouais](/wiki/C%C3%A9gep_de_l%27Outaouais "Cégep de l'Outaouais"), and
[Heritage College](/wiki/Heritage_College_\(Gatineau\) "Heritage College
\(Gatineau\)").

Four main public school boards exist in Ottawa: English, English-Catholic,
French, and French-Catholic. The English-language [Ottawa-Carleton District
School Board](/wiki/Ottawa-Carleton_District_School_Board "Ottawa-Carleton
District School Board") (OCDSB) is the largest board with 147 schools,[196]
followed by the English-Catholic [Ottawa Catholic School
Board](/wiki/Ottawa_Catholic_School_Board "Ottawa Catholic School Board") with
85 schools.[197] The two French-language boards are the French-Catholic
_[Conseil des écoles catholiques du Centre-
Est](/wiki/Conseil_des_%C3%A9coles_catholiques_du_Centre-Est "Conseil des
écoles catholiques du Centre-Est")_ with 49 schools,[198] and the French
_[Conseil des écoles publiques de l'Est de
l'Ontario](/wiki/Conseil_des_%C3%A9coles_publiques_de_l%27Est_de_l%27Ontario
"Conseil des écoles publiques de l'Est de l'Ontario")_ with 37 schools.[199]
Ottawa also has numerous [private schools](/wiki/Private_school "Private
school") which are not part of a board.

The [Ottawa Public Library](/wiki/Ottawa_Public_Library "Ottawa Public
Library") was created in 1906 as part of the famed [Carnegie
library](/wiki/Carnegie_library "Carnegie library") system.[200] The library
system had 2.3 million items as of
2008[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Ottawa&action=edit).[201]

## Media[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ottawa&action=edit&section=16 "Edit
section: Media")]

Further information: [Media in
Ottawa–Gatineau](/wiki/Media_in_Ottawa%E2%80%93Gatineau "Media in
Ottawa–Gatineau")

Three main daily local newspapers are printed in Ottawa: two English
newspapers, the _[Ottawa Citizen](/wiki/Ottawa_Citizen "Ottawa Citizen")_
established as _the Bytown Packet_ in 1845 and the _[Ottawa
Sun](/wiki/Ottawa_Sun "Ottawa Sun")_ , with weekly circulation of 900,197 and
274,628, respectively, and one French newspaper, _[Le Droit](/wiki/Le_Droit
"Le Droit")_.[202] Another free commuter daily paper, _[Metro
Ottawa](/wiki/Metro_Ottawa "Metro Ottawa")_ , was added in the 2000s. Several
weekly and monthly community papers are also published, including the
_Kitchissippi Times_. Multiple Canadian television broadcast networks and
systems, and an extensive number of radio stations, broadcast in both English
and French.

In addition to the market's local media services, Ottawa is home to several
national media operations, including [CPAC](/wiki/CPAC_\(TV_channel\) "CPAC
\(TV channel\)") (Canada's national [legislature
broadcaster](/wiki/Legislature_broadcaster "Legislature broadcaster"))[203]
and the parliamentary bureau staff of virtually all of Canada's major
newsgathering organizations in television, radio and print. The city is also
home to the head office of the [Canadian Broadcasting
Corporation](/wiki/Canadian_Broadcasting_Corporation "Canadian Broadcasting
Corporation"), although it is not the primary production location of most CBC
radio or television programming.

## Twin towns – sister
cities[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ottawa&action=edit&section=17 "Edit section:
Twin towns – sister cities")]

Ottawa is [twinned](/wiki/Twin_towns_and_sister_cities "Twin towns and sister
cities") with:

  * [![China](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Flag_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China.svg.png)](/wiki/China "China") [Beijing](/wiki/Beijing "Beijing"), China;[204]
  * [![Egypt](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Flag_of_Egypt.svg/23px-Flag_of_Egypt.svg.png)](/wiki/Egypt "Egypt") [Cairo](/wiki/Cairo "Cairo"), Egypt;[205]
  * [![Italy](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/03/Flag_of_Italy.svg/23px-Flag_of_Italy.svg.png)](/wiki/Italy "Italy") [Catania](/wiki/Catania "Catania"), Italy.[206]
